pitrou commented on issue #6234: ARROW-7622: [Format] Mark Tensor and SparseTensor fields required
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/6234#issuecomment-577325032
 
 
   @mrkn Is there a reason why Tensor strides default to row-major but SparseIndexCOO strides default to column-major?
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.
 
For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

mrkn commented on issue #6234: ARROW-7622: [Format] Mark Tensor and SparseTensor fields required
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/6234#issuecomment-577458810
 
 
   Actually, the default strides of SparseIndexCOO is column-major, but it isn't intentionally decided, just historically.
   At first, SparseIndexCOO only supported column-major strides because scipy.sparse.coo_matrix always has a column-major index.  When I added the support of row-major, I didn't change the default strides.  That's all.
   
   I think now is the best timing to change the default strides to row-major.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.
 
For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

pitrou commented on issue #6234: ARROW-7622: [Format] Mark Tensor and SparseTensor fields required
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/6234#issuecomment-577685276
 
 
   Actually, I think it makes sense for SparseIndexCOO to be column-major. If it is row-major, then reading a column of coordinates yields non-sequential cache-unfriendly memory accesses. If it is column-major, the coordinates are sequential.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------

pitrou commented on issue #6234: ARROW-7622: [Format] Mark Tensor and SparseTensor fields required
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/6234#issuecomment-577690372
 
 
   I'll note that pydata/sparse uses row-major order for coordinates:
   ```python
   >>> x = np.eye(4)                                                                                                                                                     
   >>> x[2, 3] = 5                                                                                                                                                       
   >>> s = sparse.COO.from_numpy(x)                                                                                                                                      
   >>> s.coords                                                                                                                                                          
   array([[0, 1, 2, 2, 3],
          [0, 1, 2, 3, 3]])
   >>> s.coords.strides                                                                                                                                                  
   (40, 8)
   ```
   
   As for scipy.sparse, it only supports 2-dim sparse tensors and stores row and column coordinates in separate arrays... (which has the same memory access properties as column-major)
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.

users@infra.apache.org

fields.description:
The Tensor and SparseTensor parts of the format are currently marked experimental. This presumably means that they are still allowed to change (and indeed they did change one month ago, in ARROW-4225). 

I suggest we take the opportunity to mark some fields required in {{Tensor.fbs}} and {{SparseTensor.fbs}}, to make input validation more robust.

cc [~mrkn], [~jacques]  and [~wesm] for opinions.
fields.summary: [Format] Mark Tensor and SparseTensor fields required

comments.body: +.5 from me. I agree with the thinking but don't actually use this. Otherwise would be +1

Agreed. Since "required" in Flatbuffers does not appear to have forward compatibility implications (see e-mail thread about this), old versions of the software would not be affected even if the current version of the files had been released to production.
I also agree with this idea.
